answers.a: Yes—chlorophylls (E140i) contain a central magnesium ion. If Mg is lost during processing (forming pheophytin), the green color dulls.

answers.q: "what is the function of the magnesium atom in a chlorophyll molecule"
answers.a: The magnesium sits at the center of the chlorin ring, coordinating four nitrogens and tuning the electronic structure to absorb light. This enables efficient energy/electron transfer in photosynthesis and contributes to the green color.

answers.q: 1 gram contains 2.68 % magnesium. how many atoms of mg will there be in 1.00 g of chlorophyll?
answers.a: At 2.68% Mg, 1.00 g contains 0.0268 g Mg ≈ 0.00110 mol (24.305 g/mol). That is about 6.6×10^20 magnesium atoms (0.00110 × 6.022×10^23).

answers.q: 2. what is the function of the magnesium atom in a chlorophyll molecule?
answers.a: The Mg ion is the central coordinating atom of the pigment’s ring, shaping the absorption spectrum so chlorophyll can harvest light and transfer energy.

answers.q: 3. what is the function of the magnesium atom in a chlorophyll molecule?
answers.a: It serves as the central metal that stabilizes the chlorin ring and enables light absorption; removing Mg alters the color and photochemistry (pheophytin formation).
In foods, E140i (chlorophylls) are natural green pigments used as a color additive to give or restore a green hue; they don’t change the taste.
As a food colorant it’s considered safe at permitted levels, but it isn’t a nutrient and has no proven health benefits at typical intake.
It’s used to color foods green—such as beverages, sauces, and confectionery—and to help maintain a natural-looking green tone in plant-based products.

answers.q: what does chlorophyll do for the body
answers.a: At the small amounts used as a color additive, it has no specific physiological benefits and is largely not absorbed.
Not usually, though it can turn stools green; high supplemental intakes may cause mild gastrointestinal upset, including loose stools, in some people.
